Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Placenta previa

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Fletcher,

You were admitted to the hospital for your placenta previa at 
38 weeks gestation. You were able to deliver a healthy baby boy. 

Please continue to take your pain medication as needed, but do 
not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking this 
medication. It is important that you do not stop taking this 
medication abruptly because it can cause withdrawal symptoms.

We wish you the best of luck with the care of your newborn!

Your healthcare team
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Marquez in 4-6 weeks for a follow-up appointment to assess the resolution of your placenta previa and discuss any further management or testing as necessary. If you experience any new symptoms or concerns before then, please contact her office immediately to schedule an earlier visit.

Discharge Disposition:

Discharge Diagnosis:
R ankle fracture
Right lower leg compartment syndrome

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: 

*Increased pain that is not controlled with medication
*Increased swelling
*Decreased sensation, movement, or reflexes
*Warmth, redness, or drainage from the incision site
*Fevers greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
*Any other concerns

**Please follow-up with your PCP within one week of discharge**

Physical Therapy:
1. Please remain non weight bearing on your right lower leg 
until you see us in follow up.
2. When you return home, please use crutches at all times when 
ambulating and do not bear any weight on your operative extremity.

Activity:
Please avoid excessive bending, lifting, twisting or pulling of 
more than 5 lbs for the next 6 weeks. This includes but is not 
limited to: housework, yard work, carrying children, etc.

You will be more comfortable if you continue to use a sling when 
you are aware that you are going to be using your arm for support 
or if you think you may be putting strain on your injury.
 
Followup Instructions:
Please schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Marquez in 2 weeks to monitor the progress of your R ankle fracture and adjust treatment as needed. During this visit, we will assess your pain levels, range of motion, and overall recovery. If you experience any increase in pain or swelling before then, please contact our office for immediate attention. Thank you for entrusting us with your care! - Your Orthopedics Team.

Name:  Michael Williams                 Unit No:   1234759
 
Admission Date:  2025-01-04              Discharge Date:   2025-01-11
 
Date of Birth:  1968-09-29             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: Dr. Rachel Sawyer

Discharge Medications:
1. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
RX *lisinopril 20 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*0
2. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 
RX *metoprolol succinate 25 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day 
Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis: 
Acute coronary syndrome
Diabetes mellitus type II 

Secondary Diagnosis: 
Hypertension 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Williams, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay at Oakwood Community Hospital.  You were admitted 
to the hospital for chest pain.  You had an angiogram performed 
which showed a blockage in one of your coronary arteries.  A 
stent was placed to improve blood flow through this artery.  In 
addition, it appears that you have diabetes mellitus type II.  
This is a chronic condition where your body does not produce 
enough insulin and therefore the cells in your body cannot use 
the glucose from food for energy.

We started you on two new medications to help prevent future 
heart attacks: metoprolol succinate 25mg daily and lisinopril 20mg 
daily.  You will need to continue taking these medications as 
long as you live with the exception of having severe shortness 
of breath where it is not relieved by sitting up or turning your 
head to one side.  Please DO NOT take any NSAIDs, such as 
ibuprofen (Advil) and naproxen (Aleve) for at least one month.

We also started you on a medication called metformin which will 
help control the level of sugar in your body.  You can continue 
to take this medication until you run out of your current supply, 
at that time please contact your doctor who can prescribe more.  

In addition to these new medications, we stopped one of your 
medications: sertraline (Zoloft) and we decreased the dose of 
your other medicine:  atenolol from 25mg daily to 0mg daily.
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Rachel Sawyer in 1 week for a follow-up appointment to review your progress and adjust treatment as necessary based on any changes in symptoms or test results. If you experience worsening chest pain, shortness of breath, or other concerning symptoms before then, please contact our office immediately to schedule an urgent visit with Dr. Rachel Sawyer.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with a cervical spine fracture 
and T 10 compression fracture. You had a collar placed in the 
ED and you have been wearing it since then. The orthopedic 
surgeons decided that this fracture did not require surgical 
intervention at this time and they are going to follow you as an 
outpatient. You will need to wear your collar until you see them 
again.

You also developed a rash on your arm with erythema, warmth and 
blanching of the skin. The most likely cause is friction from the 
collar. This should improve with time without treatment.
 
Followup Instructions:
Please return to see Dr. Julianne Patel in 2 weeks for re-evaluation of your cervical spine fracture and T10 compression fracture, as well as to discuss any further treatment or rehabilitation needs you may have at this time. If you experience any increased pain or difficulty moving your neck before then, please contact our office so we can schedule an earlier appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel

Discharge Disposition:

Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute Pancreatitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Smith,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization 
at North Christopher Medical Center.  You were admitted with 
abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and elevated liver enzymes.  
You underwent imaging studies that showed inflammation in the 
pancreas, which is consistent with pancreatitis.  Your symptoms 
improved over time with supportive care.

Please follow up with your oncologist as scheduled because you 
were recently started on a new chemotherapy regimen for your 
cancer treatment.

If you experience any of the following symptoms, please call 
your doctor or go to the emergency room immediately:
- worsening abdominal pain
- difficulty breathing
- chest pain
- lightheadedness/dizziness
- severe nausea/vomiting

We wish you all the best,

Your North Christopher Medical Center Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel in 2 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed, or sooner if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise. Please call our office to schedule this appointment at least 24 hours in advance to ensure availability. During your visit, be prepared to discuss any changes in condition or side effects from current medications. Dr. Julianne Patel will assess your overall health and provide further instructions for ongoing care. If you experience severe symptoms or have questions before your scheduled appointment, please contact our office immediately for assistance.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis: Schizophrenia
Secondary diagnoses: Bipolar disorder, depression

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Blackwood,

It was a pleasure taking part in your care during this admission to 
East Jackson Community Hospital.  You were admitted for symptoms 
of psychosis, which were likely related to the progression of 
your schizophrenia.  While you were here, we started you on an 
injectable medication called Aristada, and we also changed some of 
the medications that you take daily.

Please continue to take your medications as prescribed.  Also, 
please follow up with your outpatient psychiatrists at East Jackson Community Hospital. 
outpatient psychiatrist Dr. Julianne Patel will be starting 
you on a new medication called Latuda, which is an anti-psychotic 
medication, and we are also changing some of the other medications 
that you take daily.

Please call your doctor or go to your nearest emergency room if 
you have any worsening symptoms such as hearing voices, seeing 
things that are not there, having thoughts of suicide or homicide, 
or any other concerning symptoms. 

It was a pleasure taking part in your care!

Sincerely,
Your East Jackson Community Hospital Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel in 2-3 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed. Please notify her office if you experience any worsening of symptoms or have concerns before then.

was found that you have very high blood pressures which can be 
dangerous for your heart and brain.  We started you on 
medications for this and recommend that you follow-up closely 
with primary care to manage your blood pressure.

physician if you have any concerning symptoms such as chest 
pain, shortness of breath, lightheadedness or dizziness.

in 1 week and then with a cardiologist at Northbrook Community Hospital.  
Please see the schedule below for the dates and times of these 
appointments.  

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.

Sincerely,
Your Heartland Regional Hospital Team

Discharge Medications:
1. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO DAILY 
RX *atorvastatin [Lipitor] 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Daily Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Omeprazole 40 mg PO BID 
RX *omeprazole [Prilosec] 20 mg 2 capsule(s) by mouth Twice a 
Day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
4. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg PO TID 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Coronary Artery Disease

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Mitchell,

You were admitted to the hospital because you had a 
myocardial infarction (heart attack). You underwent cardiac 
catheterization and a stent was placed in your left anterior 
descending artery, which is one of the main blood vessels that 
supplies oxygenated blood to your heart muscle. The catheter 
procedure went well without complications.

You were transferred to the cardiac floor for further management 
of your chest pain symptoms. You continued to have chest pain 
when you would walk or go up stairs but this resolved within 10-15 
minutes of resting in a chair or bed.

Your heart rate and blood pressure remained stable. There was no 
evidence of a pulmonary embolism on imaging, but we recommend 
that you follow-up with your primary care doctor to get an EKG 
done at the time of your annual physical exam this year.
 
Followup Instructions:

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with chest pain and we found a blockage in one 
of the arteries that brings blood to your heart.  We performed 
a procedure called a cardiac catheterization, which involved 
using a thin tube (called a catheter) to inject dye into the 
arteries of your heart. This allowed us to see the extent of the 
blockages and we found one blockage in your right coronary 
artery that was partially blocking blood flow to your heart.  
We also performed a procedure called an angioplasty, which 
involved using a balloon to open up the blockage in your artery.  
After this procedure, you were monitored overnight with a EKG 
and a monitor attached to your chest and no new signs of damage 
were seen.

You will need to take aspirin and Plavix (Plxy) to prevent blood 
from clotting inside your arteries.  You should also follow up 
with the cardiologist Dr. Julianne Marlowe in the next few days or 
week, as they would like to see you for a check of your heart's 
electrical activity.

It is important that you continue to take care of yourself after 
this event by eating well and continuing to exercise regularly. 
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Marlowe in 1 week for re-evaluation of your coronary artery disease and to discuss further management options, or sooner if you experience any worsening symptoms such as chest pain or shortness of breath. Be sure to inform her office staff of your need for urgent follow-up upon scheduling your appointment. Regular monitoring by Dr. Julianne Marlowe will help ensure that your condition continues to improve and that any necessary adjustments are made to your treatment plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Fothergill,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your admission to 
the hospital.  You were admitted for shortness of breath and low 
blood pressure. We felt that this was due to the heart not 
pumping well, which is concerning given your history of heart 
disease and prior heart attack. The echocardiogram showed that 
your left ventricle has decreased pumping function, but it did 
not show any evidence for a significant blockage in one of the 
heart's blood vessels.

In order to help you better tolerate activities while at home, 
we have started you on an ACE inhibitor (Losartan) and beta 
blocker (Metoprolol Succinate XL). These medications are very 
important in helping your heart function well. We also want to 
make sure that your blood pressure does not become too low when 
you are at home.

We made a change to your medications while you were here in the 
hospital. Please stop taking Amlodipine (Norvasc) and start 
taking Losartan 100 mg once daily. Also, please take Metoprolol 
Succinate XL 50mg once daily. 

While you are recovering at home, it is very important that you 
do not smoke or be around others who are smoking. It is also very 
important to stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water.

Please follow up with your primary care physician and 
cardiologist as scheduled below.

Return to see Dr. Julianne Patel in 4 weeks for a re-evaluation of your cardiogenic shock diagnosis and to assess any changes in your condition since discharge. Dear Ms. Jensen,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization 
at Bayshore Medical Center.  You were admitted to the Surgery 
service after having abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 
several days. An ultrasound of your abdomen showed that you have 
a condition called diverticulitis which is an inflammation of 
your colon. This most likely occurred due to a blockage in one 
of the small pouches in your intestine. In order to make sure this 
does not get worse, we are sending you home with antibiotics and 
to follow up with your surgeon who will monitor you for signs of 
infection or other complications.

Your abdominal pain improved while you were here and you have 
been tolerating a regular diet. We recommend that you continue 
to eat small frequent meals to decrease the discomfort from 
abdominal distension. If your symptoms worsen, please seek care 
from your primary physician or return to the emergency room if 
you believe your condition is life threatening.

Please follow up with your surgeon in one week for a post op 
visit and as you will be discharged on antibiotics, this visit is 
important so that we can assess whether further treatment is 
required. We also recommend that you continue to take your other 
medications as prescribed by your physicians prior to coming to 
the hospital.

Please seek medical attention if you develop any of the signs 
and symptoms listed below:
* severe abdominal pain
* vomiting and inability to keep down fluids or food
* fevers greater than 101 degrees
* chills
* blood in stool
* chest pain

Thank you for allowing us to be a part of your care,
Your Bayshore Medical Center Team

1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
2. Please follow up with your PCP within one week and inform 
them that you were admitted for a tibial plateau fracture. They 
will need to re-evaluate you for medication refills as needed.
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain improves, please decrease 
the amount of pain medication. This medication can cause constipation 
so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool 
softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect.
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary physician.
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in four weeks.

 

 
Followup Instructions:
Follow up with Dr. Julianne Marlowe in 1-2 weeks for a post-operative check and to assess the healing progress of your tibial plateau fracture. During this visit, you will also have the opportunity to discuss any concerns or questions you may have with Dr. Julianne Marlowe directly. Please contact our office if you experience any increase in pain or swelling before your scheduled follow-up appointment.

with one of the interventional cardiologists at South Chrisman Medical Center.

you have any shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, 
lightheadedness, dizziness, or any other symptoms that are of 
concern to you.

Your Cardiology Team

medications.

clock for severe pain, and decrease to q6hr (every 6 hours) as 
your pain improves.

When to Call Your Doctor

additional medication.

- Increased redness, swelling or drainage from your incision(s).

- Fever >101.5 (oral) degrees or 100.5 (rectal) degrees for more 
than 24 hours.

- Chest pain, shortness of breath or any other symptoms that are 
concerning to you.

1) Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, fevers greater than 101.5, 
vomiting, lightheadedness or dizziness, difficulty urinating, 
bright red vaginal bleeding requiring >2 pads/hour, abnormal 
vaginal discharge, headaches, visual changes or ringing in your 
ears.

as scheduled and inform them of any change in your condition.

3) You may resume sexual activity unless otherwise instructed.

medications without discussing this with your physician first.  
You have been given a prescription for pain medication.  We 
recommend that you take less than the maximum dose and decrease 
the frequency of use over time as your pain improves.

5) You may not drive while taking narcotics (do not drive if you 
have to take more than 2 grams of narcotic per day).

6) If you are instructed to wear knee high compression stockings, 
please continue wearing these for the next several weeks as 
recommended by your physician. 
 
7) Please use birth control until you wish to become pregnant at 
which time you should stop.  You may discuss options with Dr. Julianne Sawyer when you see her.

experience: fever >101, severe abdominal pain, abnormal vaginal 
bleeding requiring >2 pads/hr, significant changes in bowel or 
bladder function, or any other concerns you may have.

soon as possible.

draws, please complete these tests and follow up with your OB 
as directed.

your abdomen towards your spine (this is the area where you had 
your operation).

routine as soon as possible.

please continue this medication indefinitely unless directed 
to stop by your physician.

14) Please call the office if there is a change in your vaginal 
bleeding pattern.  You may need to come into the office for 
further evaluation.
 
15) If you have any questions or concerns regarding your care at 
the time of discharge, please contact your OBSTETRICS doctor at Mckinney Regional Hospital. 

16) Please follow-up with your PCP as soon as possible

17)Please note that it is normal to feel somewhat "washed out" for 
a few days following delivery

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER SPINE SURGERY

- You were in the hospital for 1 day after your surgery. This is 
a normal amount of time for this type of procedure. 

- Please call the office if you experience any numbness, 
tingling, weakness, loss of reflexes, or bowel/bladder dysfunction 
in your lower extremities.

- Avoid heavy lifting, pushing, pulling, or bending for 6 weeks 
as this can put additional stress on your spine and the surgical 
site. 

- You should be able to shower in 2 days after surgery. Let the 
water run over your incision; do not use a shower head to spray 
the area.

- Do not take any anti-inflammatory medication such as Motrin, 
Ibuprofen, Aspirin, Advil, Aleve, or Nuprin for at least 4 weeks 
as this can further irritate the spine and surgical site. 

- You may start driving when you feel comfortable and able to do 
so, but no driving while taking narcotics.

- Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
Followup Instructions:
Follow up with Dr. Julianne Sawyer in 2 weeks for a post-operative check and to assess progress towards recovery from the lumbar L3-L4 hemilaminectomy and bilateral decompression procedure. During this visit, you will have the opportunity to discuss any questions or concerns you may have about your ongoing care and rehabilitation. Be sure to contact our office if you experience any worsening of symptoms or have difficulty tolerating activity between now and your scheduled follow-up appointment.

rib cage from the vertebrae.
- You may resume sexual activity as soon as you feel comfortable 
doing so, but no heavy lifting or straining for 6 weeks.

Wound Care
- Keep your incisions clean and dry. You may shower starting 5 
days after surgery, no tub baths or swimming for at least 6 
weeks.
- If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own.
- If you have staples, they will be removed by a visiting nurse in 
about 2 weeks.

Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you experience any of the 
following
- Increasing pain or swelling not relieved by elevation and 
rest.
- Increased redness or drainage from your incision.
- Fever >101.5F
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting
- Any other concerns
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Marquez in 1 week for a post-operative check and to discuss further management of your T2, T5, and T9 tumor diagnosis. During this visit, we will assess your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan. Please call our office to schedule an appointment at least 24 hours prior to your scheduled follow-up date.

You were admitted to the hospital for an ovarian cyst. This was 
removed surgically and sent to pathology, which did not show any 
cancer cells in it. You tolerated this surgery well without any 
complications. 

You are now ready to be discharged home with the following 
instructions:

Do not drive until you are no longer taking pain medications.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any narcotics 
(pain relievers such as oxycodone, percocet, vicodin) for 2 weeks 
after surgery. You may use over the counter pain medication like 
Tylenol or ibuprofen if needed.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber to prevent constipation
You should not eat constipating foods such as cheese, dairy, 
milk, ice cream, bread, pasta, beef, pork for 4-6 weeks after 
surgery. You may have small amounts of these foods but they are 
not good for you right now.
You may shower and wash incisions gently with warm soapy water. 
Rinse clean and pat dry. You may apply a thin layer of Vaseline or
Aquaphor with gauze over the incision. Change this dressing daily 
if it is open, otherwise change every other day. 
Do not soak your incisions in a bath or pool for at least 4-6 
weeks after surgery.
You may have a light headed feeling when standing or walking due 
to the anesthesia given during surgery. This will improve over 
time and you will get used to it. If you feel faint, sit down or 
lay down and put your feet up, drink some water and take slow 
deep breaths. 
You may experience fatigue (feeling tired) for a few weeks after 
surgery. You should try to walk several times per day for 10-15 
minutes.
Your appetite will be decreased immediately after surgery but 
will improve with time. Try small frequent meals and snacks. It 
is normal for your bowel movements to be slow at first and they 
will return to normal within a few weeks. If you have severe 
diarrhea or blood in the stool,

PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS
=================
Coronary artery disease

SECONDARY DIAGNOSES
====================
Hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. Nelson,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at East Christopher Community Hospital.  You were admitted for chest pain, 
which was concerning for a heart attack. An ultrasound test 
called an echocardiogram did not show evidence of a heart attack, 
but it showed that one of your blood vessels was blocked by a 
plaque (like hard fat). This plaque can cause damage to the 
blood vessel and lead to a heart attack if left untreated.

A procedure called angiography was performed. It is an imaging 
test where dye is injected into your blood vessels, and pictures 
are taken using special X-ray cameras. The test showed that one of 
your arteries was blocked by the plaque. This artery supplies 
blood to your heart muscle. A stent (a small mesh tube) was placed 
in this artery to keep it open and allow blood to flow freely.

You are being discharged home with a new medication called 
atorvastatin, which will help lower cholesterol in your blood.
Cholesterol can contribute to the formation of plaque in your 
blood vessels. You should also continue taking aspirin daily to 
help prevent another blockage from occurring.

It is very important that you follow up with Dr. Julianne Sawyer as an outpatient. She will check how well your heart is doing and remove any stitches or staples that may be needed. If you have a fever, chest pain, shortness of breath, or any other concerning symptoms before your appointment, please call her office immediately.
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Sawyer in 1-2 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as necessary. Please notify the doctor's office if you experience any worsening symptoms or concerns between appointments.

Discharge Instructions:
You have been discharged with a right mini-open posterior 
lumbar fusion at L3-L4.  Please follow the instructions below to 
ensure a safe and healthy recovery:

1) You should be able to resume your normal diet, but it is best 
to avoid heavy lifting for several weeks after surgery.
2) If you have been instructed to wear a brace or back cast, 
you must wear it at all times until follow-up with the doctor.  
You will not need this once the bone in your back has healed, 
but this may take as long as 6 weeks to 3 months for some people.  
Please do not get the brace wet if you plan on wearing it after 
this time.
3) You may shower immediately after surgery, but you must cover 
the incision with plastic bags or waterproof bandages in order 
to keep your incision dry until follow-up.
4) You should NOT smoke for several months to allow the bone and 
soft tissue of the spine to heal.  Smoking can lead to a long 
term increase in pain after surgery, so it is very important 
that you stop smoking for good.
5) It is normal to feel tired or "washed out" after this type of 
surgery.  You should try to rest as much as possible and avoid 
heavy activity until your follow-up visit with the doctor.
6) You may resume your regular activities at your own pace when 
you are no longer experiencing pain.  Please do NOT lift anything 
greater than 5 pounds for several weeks after surgery, or until 
your follow-up visit with the doctor.

MEDICATIONS:
1) Percocet (oxycodone/acetaminophen):  Please take as directed 
by your physicians to control post-operative pain.
2) Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen: This medication is NOT allowed by 
our hospital or surgery center.  It must be discontinued 
immediately.  
3) Tylenol (acetaminophen):  Take as needed for pain.  Please do 
not exceed 4 grams of acetaminophen per day.

Please note that narcotic pain medications can cause constipation

You were admitted to the hospital with left groin pain and found 
to have a hernia at the time of surgery on 4/10/2025. Your postoperative course was complicated by pain, nausea, and vomiting. 
However, you are now tolerating a regular diet, your pain is well 
controlled with oral analgesics, and you are ready to be 
discharged home.

Please follow these instructions to ensure a speedy recovery:

MEDICATIONS:
1)  Resume taking all medications as directed on discharge.
2)  Continue to take prescription pain medication as directed. 
This medication can cause constipation; therefore, you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(e.g., colace) as needed to prevent this side effect.
3)  Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking narcotic 
pain medications.

ACTIVITY:
1)  Resume normal activity slowly. You will be more comfortable 
and less likely to pull your hernia if you go up and down stairs 
only, get up from a seated position only, and refrain from lifting 
greater than 10 pounds for the next few weeks.
2)  Avoid heavy lifting, pushing, or pulling greater than 10 lbs 
for 6 weeks.
3)  You may resume sexual activity as soon as you feel comfortable 
doing so. However, do not use a seat belt if you have a inguinal 
hernia repair.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

*Severe pain that is not relieved by your pain medication.
*Prolonged or severe vomiting where you are not able to keep 
down fluids or your medications.
*Fevers >101.5 degrees F for 24 hours.
*Shaking chills
*Redness, swelling, increased drainage from incision(s)
*If you see dark or "currant jelly" blood when you use the 
bathroom

Thank you for allowing us to be a part of your care!
 
Followup Instructions:
Follow up with Dr. Julianne Patel in 1 week to have your sutures removed and to discuss post-operative care instructions for your left inguinal hernia repair. Dear Ms. Moreno, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay.  
You were admitted to the hospital for evaluation of your 
esophagus with biopsies taken.  The results showed that you have 
eosinophilic esophagitis which is an allergic reaction causing 
swelling and inflammation in the esophagus leading to difficulty 
swallowing, abdominal pain, food getting stuck, etc.

The treatment for this disease involves dilating the narrowed 
area of your esophagus and taking steroids to suppress your 
allergic response.  You also have GERD which may be contributing 
to your symptoms and you should continue to take your medications 
for that condition as well.

Brain Stem Stroke

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Maddox,

You were admitted to the Rodriguez after presenting with slurred 
speech, facial drooping and numbness on your right side. You 
were found to have a stroke involving multiple areas of the 
brain including the brainstem which is responsible for many of 
the functions that control breathing and swallowing.

You had several episodes while you were here where you stopped 
breathing and required assistance with ventilation. We made some 
adjustments to your medications in an attempt to prevent this 
from happening again, but it has been noted that you have a 
history of having difficulty breathing on the phone and it is 
important that you continue to use your inhaler as prescribed.

You had difficulty swallowing while here at times, and we 
performed several swallow studies. You will need to follow up 
with a speech therapist in order to determine whether or not you 
will require a feeding tube in the future.

We started you on a medication called oxycoDONE for pain control 
and this was increased as needed. We recommend that you continue 
to take this for pain and also try some of the other measures we 
discussed such as heat, ice and tylenol.

You had an MRI of your brain which showed evidence of your 
stroke. You will need to follow up with a neurologist in order to 
determine whether or not you require any further treatment.
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Michael Reed in 4 weeks for re-evaluation and adjustment of treatment plan as needed, or sooner if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise. During this time, please continue to take your medications as prescribed and follow up with your primary care physician for routine check-ins. If you experience any severe headache, numbness, weakness, or vision changes, seek immediate medical attention by calling Dr. Michael Reed's office or visiting the nearest emergency room.

not operate heavy machinery or drive a car while taking these 
medications.

hours or is worsening at any time, call your surgeon's office for 
further instructions.
* You may restart your home blood thinner (Coumadin) today. Please

in your lungs, called a pulmonary embolism. You also fell and 
hit your head before being brought to the hospital, where it was 
found that there was bleeding in between the covering of your

of a blood clot in the vessels of your brain. You were started 
on a medicine called warfarin to help prevent another pulmonary 
embolism from occurring.

Discharge Condition:

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Rylan,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay 
here at South Bay Community Healthcare System.  You were 
admitted with pain and discomfort in your abdomen, nausea, and 
vomiting.  We performed an ultrasound to evaluate the gallbladder 
which showed inflammation and sludge, consistent with acute 
cholecystitis (gall bladder infection).  This was likely caused 
by a stone that had become lodged in the bile ducts of your 
liver.  You were treated with IV antibiotics which helped to 
resolve your symptoms.

On the day after admission you underwent surgery to remove your 
gallbladder and also did a procedure called ERCP where the stones 
were extracted from the bile ducts of your liver.  You tolerated 
the procedure well, had a good appetite post operatively with no 
more pain or nausea.  The pathology of the gall bladder was 
examined by pathologists at South Bay Community Healthcare System. and showed normal findings for gallbladder tissue.
The ERCP showed that there were stones in your bile ducts.  You 
were treated with antibiotics and we will follow you to make sure 
that the infection does not recur.

You are now ready to be discharged home, please call your doctor 
or return to the emergency department if you have any worsening of 
your symptoms or any new concerning symptoms such as severe pain, 
nausea, vomiting, fevers, chills, abdominal distension etc.
 

It was a pleasure taking care of you,
Your Bayshore Medical Center Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Matthew Smith in 2 weeks for a follow-up appointment to assess the healing progress and address any concerns related to your recent surgery for acute cholecystitis and choledocholithiasis. Please call our office to schedule this appointment at least 24 hours prior to ensure availability. If you experience increased pain, nausea, or vomiting between now and then, contact Dr. Matthew Smith's office immediately for further guidance. We will provide you with a medication refill list during your follow-up visit as needed. Thank you for allowing us to be a part of your care!

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
admission to Oakwood Community Hospital.  You were admitted for 
your abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, short 
of breath, weakness and weight loss.  We found gallstones in the 
gallbladder with signs and symptoms consistent with an acute 
cholecystitis, or inflammation of the gallbladder.  We did not do 
a cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) because 
of your heart condition.  Your gall bladder will most likely 
permanently stop functioning.  You may continue to have some 
abdominal pain and bloating but this should improve with time.

We treated you with antibiotics for your acute cholecystitis, 
and we are stopping the antibiotics as of today (day of 
discharge).  We gave you a medication called Ursodiol that will 
help dissolve the gallstones.  You can continue to take this 
medication after discharge until further notice.

Please follow up with Dr. Julianne Sawyer on the day and time 
listed below.  Please call our office at least one week prior to 
schedule or cancel this appointment.  

We wish you all the best,

Your Oakwood Community Hospital Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Sawyer in 1-2 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed based on ongoing symptoms. If symptoms worsen before then, please contact her office immediately for further guidance.

had several episodes where you fell to the ground and you lost 
consciousness for a few seconds. We did a MRI scan of your brain 
and spinal cord which showed that you have damage in both areas, 
but more importantly it showed that there is no sign of bleeding 
or stroke in your brain. This suggests that your symptoms are due 
to an injury to your brain rather than to an acute event such as 
a stroke or a bleed.

not find anything abnormal. We had you followed by the neurology 
team who were also happy with your progress and agreed that you 
should be sent home to continue your recovery at home. 

Please take all of your medications as prescribed and follow up 
with your appointments as scheduled.

Thank you for letting us participate in your care here at Oakwood Community Hospital.

your last chemotherapy treatment, but it is okay to go for a walk 
or do some light stretching immediately.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Smith,

It was a pleasure taking care of you here at the Mitchell
Neuroscience Institute.  You were admitted after being diagnosed
with an aneurysm in your brain, which was treated with a procedure
called coiling.  This is a common treatment for aneurysms and it 
was done successfully.

Please note that you may still have some headaches following the
procedure.  This can be controlled with pain medications such as 
Ibuprofen or Tylenol.  If your headache worsens, becomes more 
constant, or associated with nausea/vomiting, please contact us 
at the number below for further advice.

You should also continue to increase your intake of fluids and
keep up a high fiber diet to prevent constipation which is a 
common side effect of this type of procedure.  If you are not 
passing stools every day or if you have nausea/vomiting with 
constipation, please contact us for further advice.

You should also resume taking your home medications as prescribed
prior to admission, except while taking the pain medication 
listed below.

Thank you again for letting us participate in your care here at
the Smith.

Sincerely,

Your Allen Neurosurgery Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel in 2 weeks to monitor progress and assess response to treatment. Please call our office to schedule this appointment or notify us if you experience any worsening of symptoms before then.

Dear Ms. Brown,

It was a pleasure taking care of you here at Oakwood Community Hospital.  You were admitted 
for shortness of breath and found to have fluid overload in your lungs. We gave you 
medications to remove the excess fluid, and we started you on new doses of Lasix, 
which is a medication that removes excess salt from the body. We are also going to 
change your dialysis prescription to try to help improve your blood pressure.

We think that some of the shortness of breath was due to the fact that your lungs are 
not able to expand as well as they should be because your ribs and lung tissue have 
become stiffer over time, likely from a long history of chronic obstructive 
pulmonary disease.  We would like you to follow-up with Dr. Julianne Patel at your next dialysis 
appointment.

We are transferring you back to the home care agency for continued skilled nursing 
care.  You will continue to need assistance with most aspects of daily living, but we 
think that you will be able to return home to live comfortably. We wish you all the 
best!

Sincerely,
Your Oakwood Community Hospital Team

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Jensen,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
hospitalization at West Michael Medical Center. You were 
admitted for concern that your chronic pancreatitis flare may 
be complicated by an infection, likely caused by a urinary tract 
infection or a bladder infection. While you were here, we 
obtained blood cultures and urine tests which showed signs of 
bacteria in your blood. We treated this with antibiotics called 
piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn) and vancomycin. You also had an ERCP 
done on Thompson to help relieve blockage in the ducts of your 
pancreas, which can lead to flare ups of your pancreatitis.

You are now being discharged home with the following changes:
- Please continue taking all medications as prescribed.
- Please follow up with your primary care physician and 
gastroenterologist as scheduled.
- You may resume a regular diet.
- Do not consume alcohol. 

Weigh yourself every day in the morning, call MD if weight goes 
up by 3lbs in one day
Please seek medical attention if you develop any of the 
following:
- New onset of tremors or seizures
- Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status
- Any signs of infection: fever >101.4, chills, increased redness 
or drainage from a wound, increased or new joint pain
- Any worsening of symptoms or any new symptoms that concern you

If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to 
call the gastroenterology clinic at West Michael Medical Center. 

Good luck,

Your South Michael Medical Center Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Patel in 3 weeks for a repeat endoscopy and re-evaluation of your chronic pancreatitis flare. During this time, please monitor your symptoms closely and contact her office if you experience any worsening or new onset of pain, nausea, or other concerning side effects. Schedule this follow-up appointment as soon as possible to ensure timely evaluation by Dr. Julianne Patel.

if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved 
by your medication, fever >101.5, shaking chills, increasing red

to surgical incisions. No lotions or powders to incisions.

visit with your surgeon. If you have steri-strips (paper thin 
strips), they will fall off on their own in the next few days to 
weeks and do not need to be removed.

Please resume all regular home medications unless otherwise 
instructed. You may also take any new medications as prescribed.

Incision Care
* Please call your surgeon or return to the emergency department 
if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved 
by your medication, fever >101.5, shaking chills, increasing red 
color or drainage from your incision, chest pain, shortness of 
breath or nausea/vomiting with inability to keep down fluids/food.
* You may shower and wash surgical incisions gently with warm soapy 
water, no baths or swimming for 4 weeks. Avoid direct sun exposure 
to surgical incisions. No lotions or powders to incisions.

Activity
* We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
* You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace as you feel comfortable.

Diet
* Please eat a light diet for the first week after surgery. You 
may advance to regular foods if tolerated.
* Avoid eating greasy or fatty foods, and try not to drink too 
much of liquids or carbonated beverages (such as soda) for 2 
weeks after surgery. 

You will be followed by your primary care physician as an 
outpatient. We recommend that you make an appointment with them 
within the next week.

Please call your surgeon's office to schedule a follow-up 
appointment within the next 1-2 weeks.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Slade,

You were admitted after having a transient event with 
difficulty speaking and understanding. You had a CT scan of the 
brain that was unremarkable, but you had an MRI brain which did 
not show any signs of stroke. A Doppler ultrasound of your neck 
vessels showed no evidence of carotid artery disease.

You were diagnosed with a transient ischemic attack (TIA), also 
known as a "mini-stroke". This is when the blood supply to the 
brain is temporarily interrupted, leading to temporary loss of

active and soft without tenderness.

Ambulatory status: Independent Ambulation

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with symptoms of chest pain.  Your EKG showed 
changes consistent with a heart attack but your labs did not 
show the changes we would expect with this diagnosis.  You had 
a cardiac catheterization which showed some narrowing in one of 
the arteries that goes to your heart muscle and this was opened 
up during the procedure.  The area that went without blood flow 
during the procedure was treated with a drug called nitroglycerin 
which helped restore blood flow to the heart muscle.  
You were also started on medications for high blood pressure, 
which you will need to continue when you leave the hospital.
The cardiac catheterization revealed that one of the arteries 
that goes to your heart is 90% blocked. The other artery has a 
blockage but it is not as significant.

If you develop new chest pain or shortness of breath, call your 
doctor or go to the emergency room immediately.

It is very important that you continue to take all of your 
medications as prescribed.

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
Heartland Home Health Agency
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Coronary artery disease

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Morales,

It was a pleasure taking care of you here at Lincolnwood Community Hospital.  You were admitted to the hospital 
with chest pain that was concerning for a heart attack, but it 
was determined that your heart muscle did not suffer damage 
from being deprived of blood supply. 

You had an angiogram performed which showed that one of your 
heart arteries (the left anterior descending artery) is about 
to close off completely and you need to have this done before 
it causes another heart attack.  You were offered a procedure 
called a stent placement, but the interventional cardiologist 
felt that it was not safe for you to undergo this procedure at 
this time. Instead, he recommended that you discuss with your 
primary care physician whether or not you should have an 
angiogram performed of your neck and legs arteries as well as 
your heart arteries in the future.

You were started on a blood thinner called Aspirin which you 
should continue to take daily for at least 6 months. You also 
were started on a medication called Lisinopril, and this can 
also help prevent you from having another heart attack in the 
future. 

It is very important that you follow up with your primary care 
physician in the next couple of weeks so he can discuss with 
you whether or not you should have your neck and leg arteries 
examined in the future.

If you have any questions, please call Dr. Julianne Patel at Lincolnwood Community Hospital.
 
Followup Instructions:
Please schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel in 4-6 weeks to assess the progression of your coronary artery disease treatment and discuss any necessary adjustments to your medication regimen. During this visit, Dr. Julianne Patel will review your test results and provide personalized guidance on maintaining optimal heart health. Please contact our office if you experience any worsening symptoms or have concerns between now and then. Thank you for entrusting us with your care!

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Blackwood,  

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay. 

You were admitted for evaluation and treatment of bilateral knee 
pain. You underwent physical therapy who recommended that you 
continue to work out with weights 3 times per week for strength 
and endurance. In addition, they recommended that you also 
incorporate some exercises for flexibility such as stationary 
bike or swimming. They felt that this would help your knees feel 
better and will also allow you to continue to participate in 
your hobbies without pain. You should take the oxycodone as 
needed but do not use it daily, try to wean off of it by the end 
of the week.  If you find yourself still needing this medication 
for pain on a daily basis, please see your primary care doctor or 
return to the emergency department for further evaluation.  

Please call Dr. Julianne Marquez office at East Jamesport Community Hospital. and 
schedule a follow up appointment in 2 weeks.  We will evaluate 
your progress and adjust treatment plan as needed during this 
visit. 

Please note that narcotic pain medications can cause constipation 
and you should drink plenty of water daily and take stool softner 
to prevent this side effect. You may also use colace or miralax if 
needed to keep bowel movements regular.  If you go more than 3 days 
without having a bowel movement, please contact your primary care 
physician for further evaluation. 

Please follow up with your primary physician within the next two 
weeks for routine post-operative check-up and management of pain.

If you experience any of the following symptoms, call Dr. Julianne Marquez office at East Jamesport Community Hospital. or go to the nearest Emergency Department for immediate attention:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increased swelling of your knee
- Difficulty moving your knee
- Drainage from your incision site

Sincerely,
Your Andrews Care Team  

 
Followup Instructions:
Please schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Marquez in 1-2 weeks to assess progress and adjust treatment plan as needed for bilateral patellofemoral pain syndrome management. During this visit, you should bring any medication lists or records from previous care providers that may be relevant to your ongoing treatment. Please contact our office if you experience increased pain or discomfort before your scheduled follow-up appointment.

Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week.
  
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing restrictions strictly.

- Take your pain medicine as directed. If the pain medication is 
too sedating, take it at bedtime only. You can switch from 
narcotic pain medicines (oxycodone, percocet) to tylenol and 
ibuprofen or advil when you are tolerating a diet of solid foods.

- Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking narcotic 
pain medicine.
  
- Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. You 
may have been given new prescriptions for pain control or other 
medications - please take these as directed until they run out, 
then resume the original medication.
  
- You may shower and wash incisions with water. No baths or 
swimming for at least 4 weeks. Any stitches or staples that need 
to be removed will come out in 2 weeks.

- If you were given steri-strips (small paper strips) they will 
fall off on their own within the first two weeks after surgery.
  
- It is important to continue to ambulate several times per day 
and to keep your operative joint moving as much as possible.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Mcdonald,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at St. Catherine Regional Hospital.  You were admitted to the hospital 
because of an abdominal aortic aneurysm which is a bulge in your 
blood vessel that carries blood from your heart to your legs, 
which could rupture and cause death.

You had endovascular repair of your aneurysm, a procedure where 
a stent graft was placed inside the aneurysm through small 
incisions in your groin. This will prevent the aneurysm from 
rupturing in the future. You are now ready to be discharged home.
Please follow the instructions below:

Take all of your medications as prescribed, unless otherwise 
discussed with your physician.
You may eat a regular diet.
Exercise should be limited to walking; do not lift, push or 
pull anything greater than 10 pounds.
You may shower and wash incisions gently with warm soapy water, 
then pat dry. Do NOT rub or scrub at the incision site.

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
experience any of the following:
 
Severe pain that is not relieved by your medication, or 
changing your position.
New or increasing swelling in your legs, feet, and/or hands.
Fever greater than 101 F for 24 hours or chills.
Any change in your bowel habits, such as diarrhea, constipation 
or black stools.
Any signs of infection at the site where the catheter was 
inserted (redness, swelling, pain, drainage).
If you are instructed to monitor your temperature and it is 
greater than 101.5 F for 24 hours or greater than 100.5 F for 48 
hours.
Any bleeding from your incision sites or any area on your body.

It was a pleasure taking care of you at St. Catherine Regional Hospital! 

Sincerely,
Your Mclean Surgical Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Please schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel in 4-6 weeks to assess the stability and healing progress of the abdominal aortic aneurysm repair surgery. During this visit, we will also review any medication changes or further instructions as necessary. If you experience any increased pain, swelling, or other concerning symptoms before then, please contact our office immediately to schedule an urgent appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel. Thank you for entrusting us with your care!

cause injury to your soft tissues and lead to infection of the 
pins in your leg.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Jensen,

You were admitted to the hospital after your heart 
monitor showed signs that you had a small heart attack. You did 
not have chest pain or shortness of breath during this time, and 
your blood tests confirmed that there was damage to the muscle 
of your heart.

During your stay, we performed an angiogram which showed two of 
the arteries in your heart were partially blocked. These two 
vessels are the circumflex artery and the obtuse marginal artery. 

We placed a stent in these vessels to open them back up so that 
blood can continue to flow through the heart.

You will be on medications for the next 12 months. You should 
take Aspirin, Plavix, Metoprolol tartrate, Losartan, Atorvastatin, 
Omeprazole and Glipizide XL as prescribed.
You should follow up with your primary care doctor and 
cardiologist as scheduled.

We wish you the best,
Your Rodriguez team
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Sloane in 1-2 weeks to monitor progress and address any concerns regarding your acute coronary syndrome diagnosis. Please contact our office if you experience any worsening symptoms or have questions about your care plan before then.
